name: Mikveh
description: The mikveh is a ritual immersion bath used in Judaism for spiritual purification and transformation. Rooted in Torah commandments regarding ritual purity (tumah and taharah), the mikveh requires 'living water' (mayim chayyim) - either a natural body of water or a specially constructed pool connected to rainwater. Immersion in the mikveh marks transitions: from impurity to purity, from single to married, from Gentile to Jew. This ancient practice formed the foundation for Jewish proselyte baptism and influenced John the Baptist's baptism of repentance at the Jordan River.

Natural 'living water' that makes the mikveh ritually valid

steps.details: Remove all barriers (chatzitzah) - jewelry, dirt, makeup, bandages - that would prevent water from touching every part of the body
Enter the mikveh and stand with water covering the entire body including hair
Immerse completely underwater with all limbs spread slightly and no part of body touching the sides or bottom
After emerging, recite the blessing: 'Baruch atah Adonai, Eloheinu Melech ha'olam, asher kid'shanu b'mitzvotav v'tzivanu al ha'tevilah'
Typically immerse two more times (total of three) for added spiritual significance
Exit the mikveh in a state of ritual purity (taharah)

effects: Transformation from ritual impurity (tumah) to purity (taharah)
Completion of conversion process for proselytes
Preparation for sacred activities (Temple service, marriage, Sabbath)
Monthly renewal for married women after menstruation

symbolism.water: Mayim chayyim (living water) represents divine source of life and purity
symbolism.immersion: Complete submersion symbolizes death to old state and rebirth
symbolism.emergence: Rising from water represents new beginning and transformation
symbolism.forty_seah: Corresponds to 40 days of flood, 40 years in wilderness - periods of transformation

modernPractice: Mikveh remains central to Orthodox Jewish life. Many communities maintain mikva'ot for women's monthly immersion, conversion, and vessel immersion. Liberal movements have expanded mikveh use for spiritual occasions, healing, and gender transitions. Archaeological mikva'ot are preserved at Masada, Qumran, and throughout Israel.
